GH Hardy & W Weinberg Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium In the absence of evolution â€“ Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium. Assumptions of Hardy-Weinberg: 1. No mutation 2. Random mating 3. No gene flow (in or out) 4. Very large population size 5. No natural selection If any assumption is not met â€“ no equilibrium. Where does the Hardy- Weinberg equilibrium come from? An example Quick summaryâ€¦ 1. If you know genotype counts, you can calculate genotype and allele frequencies with count/total and alleles/total gene pool 2. If you know allele frequencies, you can predict genotype frequencies with p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1 4. You need to know homozygous recessive information or at least two other bits of data/information Putting Hardy Weinberg to work Assume 3 in every 1234 people in a Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium population are afflicted with the recessive disease m. This means that the afflicted have a homozygous recessive genotype (R = q2 when it comes to alleles). Turn to a frequency / q2 = 3/1234 = .002431 We can calculate the allele/gene frequency q = Sqrt 0.002431 = .049306 p = 1 - q = 1 - .049306 = .950694 Frequency for heterozygous carrier = 2pq = 2(.049306)(.950694) = .093750 The number of people that are carriers is 0.09375 x 1234 = 115.68 people Calculating expected genotype frequencies What if the question asks you to calculate all the expected genotype frequencies? Calculate q by finding the square root of the frequency. Then use p + q = 1 and p2 + 2pq + q2 = 1 to solve for the expected genotype frequencies. Example: 7% of individuals in a population display the recessive phenotype.
